citation.article-title: Chryseobacterium chaponense sp. nov., isolated from farmed Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar)
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Chryseobacterium chaponense sp. nov.
Chryseobacterium chaponense (cha.po.nen′se. N.L. neut. adj. chaponense pertaining to Lake Chapo, Chile, from which the Atlantic salmon harbouring the two isolates was obtained).
Cells are Gram-reaction-negative, aerobic, non-motile, non-spore-forming rods ∼1×2 μm.
Growth occurs after 48 h of incubation at 11–36 °C on nutrient agar, R2A agar and tryptic soy agar (Oxoid).
No growth occurs on MacConkey's agar (Oxoid) at 28 °C.
No growth occurs at temperatures below 4 °C and above 37 °C.
Cells grow in the presence of 0–1 % NaCl.
Colonies are smooth, yellowish, circular, translucent and shiny with entire edges when grown on nutrient agar.
A yellow pigment (KOH test-negative) is non-diffusible and non-fluorescent.

Acid is not produced from d-glucose, trehalose, d-mannitol, adonitol, l-arabinose, d-arabitol, dulcitol, erythritol, myo-inositol, lactose, maltose, melibiose, methyl-α-d-glucoside, raffinose, l-rhamnose, salicin, d-sorbitol, sucrose or d-xylose.

Negative for indole production, hydrolysis of casein, gelatin, starch, DNA and tyrosine, hydrogen sulphide production and urease, arginine dihydrolase, lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase and β-galactosidase (ONPG) activities.
The following compounds are utilized as sole carbon sources: d-glucose, maltose, acetate, propionate and l-proline.

The following compounds are not utilized as sole carbon sources: acetate, propionate, N-acetyl-d-galactosamine, N-acetyl-d-glucosamine, l-arabinose, l-arbutin, cellobiose, d-fructose, d-galactose, gluconate, glycerol, d-mannose, d-mannitol, maltitol, α-melibiose, l-rhamnose, d-ribose, sucrose, salicin, trehalose, d-xylose, adonitol, myo-inositol, d-sorbitol, putrescine, cis- and trans-aconitate, 4-aminobutyrate, adipate, azelate, fumarate, glutarate, dl-3-hydroxybutyrate, itaconate, dl-lactate, 2-oxoglutarate, pyruvate, suberate, citrate, mesaconate, l-alanine, β-alanine, l-ornithine, l-phenylalanine, l-serine, l-aspartate, l-histidine, l-leucine, l-proline, l-tryptophan, 3- and 4-hydroxybenzoate and phenylacetate.

The chromogenic substrates p-nitrophenyl α-d-glucopyranoside, bis-p-nitrophenyl phosphate, bis-p-nitrophenyl phenyl phosphonate, bis-p-nitrophenyl phosphorylcholine, 2-deoxythymidine-2′-p-nitrophenyl phosphate, l-alanine-p-nitroanilide, γ-l-glutamate-p-nitroanilide and l-proline-p-nitroanilide are hydrolysed. p-Nitrophenyl-β-d-glucopyranoside, p-nitrophenyl-β-d-galactopyranoside, p-nitrophenyl-β-d-xylopyranoside and p-nitrophenyl-β-d-glucuronide are not hydrolysed.
The major cellular fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0, anteiso-C15 : 0, iso-C13 : 0 and iso-C17 : 1ω9c.
The major hydroxylated fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0 3-OH, iso-C16 : 0 3-OH and iso-C17 : 0 3-OH.
The type strain, Sa 1147-06T (=DSM 23145T =CCM 7737T), was isolated from Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar) farmed in Lake Chapo, Chile.
